ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We did blog posts on our readings before each class.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to properly write a paper using my own voice and experience. My progression is clear from my first two essays to my final three, and I am grateful for the experience.
I learned about different types of personal writing and how to improve my own personal essays and short stories.
Ability to write clearly and succinctly and to read critically.
Improved my writing style and topic finding
Through this course I learned to critically read essays written by famous essayists and analyze details.

This was the first personal writing course I have taken, and I learned how to tailor concise writing to personal narratives. I found that personal writing is not always much easier than academic writing, and there are certain ways to make it very effective.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: One weakness was the engagement in discussion in the seminars. This is because there was a ton of reading to do for each class and never enough time for each person to comment on each piece, so what really happened was everyone would only read one assigned essay and prepare a response for it. So, there is never much insightful discussion.
It was a great course the only thing that wouldve been nice would be to have had it in person.
Great instructor, interesting essay prompts

The readings and the quality of them is very helpful for the students to see examples that will stimulate their own writing. The discussions with the professor is also very effective for understanding how and why the essays work in a specific way to achieve specific goals.  There is so many long readings assigned for each class and sometimes it is hard to do them all with the same level of engagement. It would increase student engagement through less assigned readings so that students could come up with more detailed ideas and analysis for the readings and discussions would be more fruitful.
I think the workload is fitting for a class like this. I like how most of the class is structured around reading other personal writing and discussing it. I really enjoyed that.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My seminar was great, but engagement and discussion was definitely low because of the virtual circumstances.
Our small class size lenses well to zoom meetings and posting our thoughts in blog posts were effective ways to discuss the material we read.

Most of the practices were effective even over zoom; however, breakout rooms and peer feedback through these rooms did not really work. The feedback was not effective and most of the time in the breakout rooms were spent doing nothing because people were reluctant to talk.
For a discussion class like this, I think it went as well as it could've. Discussions over Zoom were not bad.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would 100% recommend this course to any freshman coming in looking to knock out a writing credit. There is not too much reading, I have heard great things about multiple professors, the assigned essays are fun to read because they are very interesting, and the style of writing is your own so you can essentially write however you would like to, which is nice. There is a lot of writing between the rough and final revisions, but it is not bad at all because everything is based off personal experience and evidence and the essays are short.
Yes, it helped me improve as a writer and enjoy personal writing which I didnt in the past.
Yes.

Yes - you will get out of this class as much as you put into it. I got some really insightful essays and feedback on my writing that I think will prove to be a tremendous help to my writing career at Yale and beyond.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student especially if they are trying to improve their writing abilities while finding their own voice and style. The intellectual development is also an important component of this course because we are reading and analyzing many hard to read essays from successful essayists. However, it should be noted that there is an essay due almost every week so students thinking of taking this class should be ready to put in the time for that every week.
Yes, it was one of the most unique English courses I have taken, and I enjoyed it.
